text: I've been trading for 16 years that means I have made a ton of mistakes over my trading career the goal of this video is to walk you through 14 of these and there's a specific thing I want you to keep in mind during the video which is how many of these honestly do you identify with I'm curious for two reasons the first one is I'm curious how well people can objectively evaluate their own performance but then the second thing is I'm curious how far along you are in your trading journey and how many of these things you've seen because the goal of the video is to walk you through how you can overcome each of these mistakes what's up everybody Eric here welcome back to the outliers shout out to the patreon family consider signing up let's get right to it we have the first five right here and logically we'll start with number one trading has a deceptively low barrier to entry so I use the example of a martial artist of a Surfer something that's a skilled Behavior welder whatever the punchline is when you see somebody that's really good at what they do they make it look easy meanwhile when you first start doing that thing yourself you actually realize how hard it is it's called a skill Gap it's when you falsely perceive the difference between where somebody who's really good at it is and where you are the reason why

do they make it look easy meanwhile when you first start doing that thing yourself you actually realize how hard it is it's called a skill Gap it's when you falsely perceive the difference between where somebody who's really good at it is and where you are the reason why this is such a problem in trading is because anybody can start trading all you have to do is open up a brokerage account and then obviously if you look at any social media apparently everybody's always making boatloads of money somehow magically and it's really defining your mental approach to the markets which is a giant problem the markets are difficult the people that are really good at this stuff make it look easy it's not it takes time to pick it up I like to use the analogy of if you going to climb Mount Everest you have to acknowledge the Mountain itself it's the same thing in trading if you want to be a successful Trader long term you got to get ready to climb that mountain number two most people I know myself included when it comes to trading we have a just halfhazard approach what this means is think about this if you learned anything in school how did that process go you go in the first day you get an outline of some sort a syllabus then on that syllabus you're going to see all the different topics you're going to learn that are

this means is think about this if you learned anything in school how did that process go you go in the first day you get an outline of some sort a syllabus then on that syllabus you're going to see all the different topics you're going to learn that are in a logical order there's going to be some sort of homework associated projects tests all of which culminate in a Grade that evaluates your proficiency on mastering that topic that doesn't happen in trading you just start trading and the problem with that is most people do kind of shoddy homework most people aren't testing themselves objectively the issue you run into this is you kind of have a really skewed perception and a really poor learning path with one of the most complex systems I can think of an algebra equation has a Defined answer a lot of stuff in the stock market is working with with imperfect information risking Capital so the note here is when you decide to start learning to trade create a learning path for yourself one of the things I recommend for options Traders is to pick up a copy of options as a strategic investor I'm not affiliated with Lawrence McMillan at all Larry's a great dude but he wrote a great Tome about options trading that serves as that structure source for you next one kind of already hit on this markets are multivar perod essentially innumerable you can't even count

a strategic investor I'm not affiliated with Lawrence McMillan at all Larry's a great dude but he wrote a great Tome about options trading that serves as that structure source for you next one kind of already hit on this markets are multivar perod essentially innumerable you can't even count all of the inputs that the stock market has this is just a Russell 2000 and if you think about it each one of these is an individual company trying to do its business with all of its own little details associated with it and there's interdependencies between them and it just grows out to this massive quite literally global scale there's a lot going on here so the idea that you're going to just somehow bounce around picking up the right things magically and memorize it all because most people don't have a trading plan or a trading log is wild just as if you go to school you have a notebook that you take notes in you need something to take notes in whether you build out that trading plan to serve that purpose or to brainstorm ideas you need to write your thoughts down otherwise you're going to be all over the place the next one here is completely perverting how we actually make money in the stock market I call them money making mechanisms and if you think about asking a Trader how do you make money in the stock market a lot of them say

to be all over the place the next one here is completely perverting how we actually make money in the stock market I call them money making mechanisms and if you think about asking a Trader how do you make money in the stock market a lot of them say like oh I day trade well you can day trade and lose money so no that doesn't inherently make money what makes money things like being good at trading directionally whether it's up or down being good at trading volatility being good at picking good strong stocks that receive dividends or being good at picking companies that appreciate in value over time it's kind of like trading Direction but on a longer time frame the point being is it's really important to decouple the actual forces that make money versus the way you attempt to capture those forces via what products whether you trade options equities if you trade bonds or your methodology whether you're a day trader swing Trader options Trader Futures Trader Yad y yada learn what makes money then find ways to capitalize on that next up this is a really hard pill to swallow for people I started with a small account myself back in 2007 and right now I did a study and well I looked up the data in this scenario and the average Robin Hood account is 33,000 very small account the problem here is that if you're trying to trade with a

I started with a small account myself back in 2007 and right now I did a study and well I looked up the data in this scenario and the average Robin Hood account is 33,000 very small account the problem here is that if you're trying to trade with a 3,000 account you are making a ton of concessions right out of the gate you can't even sell Naked options on a bunch of things because you don't have enough money you don't have things like portfolio margin you're also going to be flagged as a day trader all of these different things lead you into this box that really forces you to trade certain structures that they might be all you have access to just because you have access to it doesn't mean it's optimal you have to understand that rarely is a vertical spread optimal in any sense there are times where it might be applicable but if you have to trade verticals cuz your account is small fine so be it that is what it is but don't delude yourself into thinking that this is a good strategy that you're really able to scale over time what you'll find is most experienced Traders move away from verticals as soon as humanly possible specifically when we're talking about options next grouping when I see new Traders this is a common misconception here we have this Trader that is successful after 13 months of trading and you know they

you'll find is most experienced Traders move away from verticals as soon as humanly possible specifically when we're talking about options next grouping when I see new Traders this is a common misconception here we have this Trader that is successful after 13 months of trading and you know they just want to acknowledge their dedication and hardship dog you've been trading for 13 you haven't even started trading yet you literally this is the infancy of trading and what I mean by this is let's take a look at this example down here it's kind of blurry cuz it's squished down but here's the punchline if you take a look at this and you see that the last bare market right here was in 2009 and if you started trading after that you didn't see another bare market for 11 years 11 years there's this reality about path path is how something moves from point A to B we know equities tend to exhibit positive drift where they go up over time but if you'll notice this chart of SPX over 10 years there's periods where it goes down and if you're trading something like this over here tle Q's I forget what time frame I tested this in but in whatever this nondescript time frame was it returned 39.5 however the path it took to get that 39.5 compound annual growth rate included a 79 draw down on your Capital so if you see something something that looks

Q's I forget what time frame I tested this in but in whatever this nondescript time frame was it returned 39.5 however the path it took to get that 39.5 compound annual growth rate included a 79 draw down on your Capital so if you see something something that looks really really good and you don't acknowledge the path it might take to get there there's a good chance that path is going to slap you in the face and Shake you out of what you're doing oh wow the other thing is you cannot accept small samples in anything that you're doing if you're a Trader you should be back testing forward testing live testing those are non-negotiables in my opinion and if you think that you've got this figured out after 13 months meanwhile you could have traded for 11 years years and not seen a a key Market condition a bare Market that's a giant problem and it's nobody's fault if you don't get a chance to see a bare Market over 11 years it's just a timing thing but that is a relic of the environment that we operate within and you have to acknowledge the shortfalls that this person even if they had traded for eight years they might have blown up their account trading the first bare Market they've ever seen because they reacted in a way that they didn't know because they've never seen this before that happens all the time time next

you know most of it and then all of a sudden risk reveals itself in some way and then you kind of identify like oh I don't even know what I don't know yet this is dangerous this is where most of my audience comes into my world because I don't deal with these people too much because they're you can't talk to them because they're too bright-eyed bushy tailed they haven't seen enough yet but these are the people that are like okay this is kind of serious I think I can figure it out but I know I have a long way to go and then this is where the sustainable growth of the skill set occurs over time but just know if you've been trading for anything less than 5 years you don't know it yet you're figuring it out hopefully you're crushing it but don't get ahead of yourself because that's where mistakes happen it's where my largest mistake happened myself next this is a common disposition I see Traders where the look at something and they'll try to see like oh you know could this work could this be a good spot for my money and what I try to recommend to people at least the way I look at things when I'm looking at trades I'm looking for reasons to say no I'm not looking for reasons to say yes this is a key differentiator between how I look at markets and other people

and what I try to recommend to people at least the way I look at things when I'm looking at trades I'm looking for reasons to say no I'm not looking for reasons to say yes this is a key differentiator between how I look at markets and other people I'm looking for the best possible place to put my money not what could conceivably work and you'll see kind of an example about this in a few minutes the last thing here is a really great saying I love this it's strong convictions loosely held this means you go through a lot of effort to build a conviction in something that's based on a lot of research but you're receptive to new information you are willing to abandon your position as soon as you receive information that leads you to do so which means you are not getting entrenched in your argument this is so common because human nature is prone to get entrenched in our position and that really doesn't benefit you in trading you have to be willing to bounce around then we also have this kind of world where Traders really foro taking responsibility this is where you see things like YOLO Traders or Lotto Traders if it's a lotto you're supposed to lose the trade so if you lose it who cares that's just completely absolving yourself of ownership of that trade it's okay to speculate speculate it's okay to take highly speculative traits don't

where you see things like YOLO Traders or Lotto Traders if it's a lotto you're supposed to lose the trade so if you lose it who cares that's just completely absolving yourself of ownership of that trade it's okay to speculate speculate it's okay to take highly speculative traits don't give yourself an out if you speculate and lose you didn't want to lose you messed up somewhere you weren't supposed to lose otherwise you wouldn't put the damn trade on so you got to abolish this kind of mindset from your approach in its entirety okay the last group here be a Trader this one is really simple in my opinion Traders all the time classify themselves I'm a day trader options Trader yada yada yada the punchline be a Trader be whatever Trader makes sense for what you're doing sometimes I'm a bullish Trader sometimes I'm a Trader sometimes I trade options sometimes I trade equities I trade whatever makes sense don't get wrapped up into identifying as a type of Trader just be a damn Trader next these are four losing habits and you've got to read the study it's called the behavior of individual investors I cite it all of the time there's a couple things you have to be aware of things like the disposition effect things like naive reinforcement these are your peers these are this is what's happening to all of the other swaths of Traders so if you want to be successful

cite it all of the time there's a couple things you have to be aware of things like the disposition effect things like naive reinforcement these are your peers these are this is what's happening to all of the other swaths of Traders so if you want to be successful it's important to look at what successful people do it's also important to look at what unsuccessful people do and don't do that so for example disposition effect when we cut winning trades too short and we let winners run don't do that naive reinforcement this is where we focus on good experiences and try to block out the bad ones because your ego doesn't like that don't do that face the music next this is a really interesting thought process and I'm not sure a lot of people consider this there are multiple ways to beat the market you don't have to beat the Topline performance every single year to outperform the market I haven't done that but I have outperformed the market almost by two times plus over the last 16 years and it's by thinking through return path so for example portfolio 1 over here it has a 7.4 average return portfolio 3 has an 88.6 average return portfolio 3 has a better return however portfolio 1 made more money 142,000 versus 139 how it had a 1.4 worse return it's because it didn't have any big draw Downs didn't have any crazy great years the best

a 7.4 average return portfolio 3 has an 88.6 average return portfolio 3 has a better return however portfolio 1 made more money 142,000 versus 139 how it had a 1.4 worse return it's because it didn't have any big draw Downs didn't have any crazy great years the best year was 10 the worst positive positive year on this side was 12 but this one 25 draw down was all the difference so think about the different ways you can outperform the market it doesn't all have to be to the Top Line next you have to abolish your normal thought patterns this bargain buying thing where if you wanted to buy deodorant yeah buy that on sale makes total sense as a consumer you're taught to bargain hunt that's actually why marketing is so smart and everything is on sale all the time it's it's the value of Something's whatever the value is but those are just marketing Poes because everybody knows that's how you're wired to think about things where if it's on sale then you should buy it CU you're getting a good deal and that's part of your experience it's all but in the markets it really doesn't work well because for example in Nvidia if you were waiting for a pullback because it's up too high and you wanted it on sale guess what you're still sitting on the sidelines then if it inadvertently has a big pullback you're like oh wow this is

it really doesn't work well because for example in Nvidia if you were waiting for a pullback because it's up too high and you wanted it on sale guess what you're still sitting on the sidelines then if it inadvertently has a big pullback you're like oh wow this is great I want to get in here well there's a reason why it's dropping at that point maybe it's not a great time to buy this is just one example other things like getting wrapped up in these new tools like options flow and dark pools and algo trading news flash retail Traders we are the tip of the tail of the dog by the time you're seeing this stuff it's been out for decades you can use these tools nothing wrong with that you're not going to find some sort of Crazy Edge in these kinds of things you still have to make it yourself the last one avoid simple explanations we went through a bunch of things here markets are complex we have a disposition to discreetly summarize things it is satiating to us we as humans want that to happen sometimes you can do that if a company has a great earnings release and then it skyrockets after earnings you could probably point at that and say yeah it went up because of earnings but never let that go too far because as soon as you start thinking that you can connect all of these dots you

company has a great earnings release and then it skyrockets after earnings you could probably point at that and say yeah it went up because of earnings but never let that go too far because as soon as you start thinking that you can connect all of these dots you run into a problem where you're now creating these different kinds of thesis that may or may not play out because you're dealing with an insanely complex system and the only thing that matters is price where does price go that's what you care about so it's cool try to develop relationships with the products try to get an idea of how things move never get too wrapped up in your own narratives because it's probably only partly true there's anything I left out throw it in the comments like subscribe share be an outlier I'll see you guys later
